problems.title: Organized Retail Crime and Shrinkage Epidemic Threatening Retailer Profitability and Employee Safety
problems.description: The retail industry faces an unprecedented crisis from organized retail crime (ORC) and shrinkage, with losses projected to exceed $150 billion by 2026. Unlike opportunistic shoplifting, ORC involves sophisticated criminal networks that steal merchandise at scale, exploit supply chain vulnerabilities, and resell goods through online marketplaces. Retailers reported an 18% increase in shoplifting incidents and a 17% increase in threats or acts of violence during theft events in 2024. The problem extends beyond physical stores into digital and e-commerce fraud, with 70% of retailers reporting increased phone scams and 55% experiencing digital fraud by ORC groups. Internal theft compounds the problem, representing approximately 30% of total shrinkage and $50 billion annually in the US alone. The crisis has forced many retailers to close stores in high-crime areas, implement controversial loss prevention measures that impact customer experience, and absorb significant losses that threaten already thin profit margins. Law enforcement limitations and prosecutors' reluctance to pursue retail theft cases further exacerbate the challenge.
problems.summary: Organized retail crime and shrinkage are causing $132+ billion in annual losses, with retailers experiencing increasing theft incidents and violence while facing limited law enforcement support and struggling to protect both inventory and employee safety.

problems.title: Retail Workforce Shortage and High Employee Turnover Crisis Disrupting Store Operations
problems.description: The retail industry is experiencing a severe labor crisis characterized by persistent workforce shortages and extraordinarily high turnover rates. With turnover reaching approximately 80% annually in some retail segments like restaurants and convenience stores, retailers struggle to maintain stable, trained workforces. As of February 2025, US job openings remained high at 7.6 million, with retail trade experiencing increased layoffs while simultaneously being unable to fill open positions. The shortage disrupts daily operations, strains managers, and negatively impacts customer experience. Contributing factors include competition for talent with higher-paying sectors, evolving employee expectations (particularly from Gen Z workers who demand fast, mobile-friendly hiring processes and flexible scheduling), burnout from understaffing, and the in-person nature of retail work limiting remote work options. Nearly 80% of retail staff work fully on-site. The cycle is self-reinforcing: understaffing leads to employee burnout, which increases turnover, which worsens understaffing. Additionally, 71% of applicants abandon job applications that take more than 15 minutes, highlighting the need for streamlined hiring processes that many retailers lack.
problems.summary: Retail faces a severe labor crisis with turnover rates up to 80% annually, persistent job vacancies, and evolving worker expectations, creating a self-reinforcing cycle of understaffing, burnout, and turnover that disrupts operations and customer service.

problems.title: Self-Checkout Technology Failures Causing Customer Frustration and Enabling Theft
problems.description: Self-checkout technology, once heralded as a solution to labor costs and checkout efficiency, has become a significant operational problem for retailers. Approximately 67% of shoppers have experienced failures or errors at self-checkout machines, leading to widespread frustration. About 25% of shoppers report machines not working properly, and customers frequently encounter scanning errors, bagging issues, and confusing interfaces. The technology has paradoxically increased theft: retailers with self-checkout kiosks report 33-60% increases in stolen goods, with over 20 million Americans admitting to stealing via self-checkout and only a third being caught. Nearly 40% of grocery registers are now self-checkout kiosks. The backlash has prompted major retailers like Walmart to remove self-checkout from some locations, and in September 2025, Long Beach, California passed the 'Safe Stores are Staffed Stores' ordinance limiting self-checkout to 15 items per kiosk and requiring employee supervision. Elderly shoppers and those making large purchases particularly dislike the technology, while younger demographics show preference for it when it works properly. The consensus emerging is that self-checkout is not inherently flawed but is often poorly implemented and inadequately staffed.
problems.summary: Self-checkout systems frustrate 67% of users with errors and malfunctions while enabling a 33-60% increase in theft, leading retailers to reconsider the technology and regulators to mandate staffing requirements.

problems.title: Checkout Queue Abandonment and Lost Sales Due to Long Wait Times
problems.description: Checkout experience failures represent the single largest source of in-store customer dissatisfaction, accounting for 21.3% of all negative feedback according to the 2025 Retail CX Insights Report. The problem is economically significant: 73% of consumers are willing to abandon purchases if forced to wait more than five minutes to check out, and in the United States, 86% of consumers have left a store due to frustration with long lines. This translates to an estimated $38 billion in lost potential sales annually. The root causes include understaffing (exacerbated by the broader labor shortage), unpredictable customer flow patterns, insufficient register capacity during peak times, and technology failures at checkout stations. The problem is particularly acute during promotional periods and holidays when customer volume spikes. Additionally, the shift to omnichannel has complicated matters as stores must now balance in-store checkout, online order pickup, and mobile checkout options simultaneously. Most shoppers have a tolerance threshold of only 5-8 minutes, after which frustration escalates rapidly. The problem creates a negative feedback loop: long lines reduce customer satisfaction, driving customers to competitors or online channels, which reduces foot traffic justifying fewer staff, which worsens wait times.
problems.summary: Long checkout wait times cause 86% of US consumers to abandon stores, resulting in $38 billion in lost annual sales, with checkout issues representing 21.3% of all in-store dissatisfaction.
